title: Miniature lab begins science experiments in outer space
title_page: Miniature lab begins science experiments in outer space | Daily Mail Online
text:
Orbiting the Earth at more than 300 miles (500 kilometres), a tiny satellite laboratory is helping scientists carry out experiments that take gravity out of the equation.
The miniature lab, which is the size of a tissue box, was launched into space last month, and the first experiments have now been completed successfully.
In space, cells and molecules behave differently, helping researchers make discoveries in fields from medicine to agriculture.
The miniature lab, which is the size of a tissue box, was launched into space last month, and the first experiments have now been completed successfully
WHY DO EXPERIMENTS IN SPACE? In space, cells and molecules behave differently, helping researchers make discoveries in fields from medicine to agriculture. Performing experiments in space allows scientists to remove accelerations that could affect the experiment. This applies to many materials experiments, such as crystal growth. It also applies to plasma physics experiments and to experiments involving studying very small perturbations and forces.
The technology was launched in February by SpacePharma, a Swiss-Israeli company.
Usually, experiments are sent up to the International Space Station and carried out with the help of astronauts, or they are conducted on parabolic airplane flights that enjoy short bursts of weightlessness.
But SpacePharma says its miniature lab is a new way for researchers to work in microgravity for extended periods.
Yossi Yamin, founder of SpacePharma, said: 'Everything can be done remotely while the system is in outer space.
'We upload the link with the command files to the lab and the experiment takes place.'
Clients then receive data and images directly from the experiments, which are carried out on custom-built glass chips and can be run multiple times to test different reactions.
The satellite currently in space holds four experiments, the first being done for a German research institute.
A second launch, also with four experiments, is scheduled for August and includes research for a top tier pharmaceutical company, Mr Yamin said.
An employee works on a miniature laboratory at Israeli-Swiss company SpacePharma's research and development site in Herzliya, Israel
By next year he hopes to begin sending up satellites that each hold some 160 experiments.
SpacePharm is not the only firm performing experiments in zero gravity conditions.
Nestle has also turned to zero gravity to perfect the foam in its chocolate mousse and coffee, while drugmakers like Eli Lilly have used it to improve drug designs.
